title: 114_hr5480
content: The "Boosting Equity for the American Middle Class Act of 2016" or the "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a refundable credit for early principal payments on certain home mortgages under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The BEAM Act of 2016 introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, limited to 50% of the payments and capped at $500 annually. There is a lifetime limitation of 10 years and a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. The BEAM Act of 2016 introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, limited to 50% of the payments and capped at $500 annually. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is defined as adjusted gross income increased by any amount excluded from gross income under specific sections. The BEAM Act of 2016 introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, limited to 50% of the payments and capped at $500 annually. Qualified home mortgage indebtedness refers to acquisition indebtedness on the taxpayer's primary residence, meeting traditional mortgage criteria. Traditional mortgage terms range from 15 to 30 years with required payments. The BEAM Act of 2016 introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, limited to 50% of the payments and capped at $500 annually. Qualified home mortgage indebtedness refers to acquisition indebtedness on the taxpayer's primary residence, meeting traditional mortgage criteria. Payments must be the same amount and made in equal intervals during the term of the indebtedness. Married individuals must file a joint return to claim the credit. The BEAM Act of 2016 introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals. The taxpayer must be treated as having been allowed the credit for 10 or more preceding taxable years if both spouses have been allowed such credits. Reporting of excess home mortgage principal payments is required, and conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new item after section 36B. Section 36C introduces early principal payments on certain home mortgages, with amendments applying to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act.
